Award.AwardTitle: GSE/DIF: Role Models Matter: Scaling Up Outreach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Techbridge and the Chabot Space and Science Center will undertake a Scale-Up Diffusion of Research-Based Innovation project called Role Models Matter. The project will supply customized training, guidance and support for role models at partner organizations--Society of Women Engineers, Girl Scout councils, and the National Girls Collaborative Project--to increase and improve the quality of STEM outreach to girls in K-12 education. The goal is to provide customized resources, training, support, and follow up for 2,200 role models to conduct outreach with approximately 87,000 girls over five years. This Scale-up is based on a proven model and resources that show evidence of increasing and improving role model outreach in engaging girls' interest in STEM careers. The project will enhance resources, allow for customization and follow up for deeper impact within three national organizations that offer STEM programs/outreach for girls. The project will be run by an experienced team with members from multiple organizations that bring extensive expertise in working with role models and girls, professional development, STEM programs, partnership support, business development, and evaluation. The Partner groups have been carefully selected and are well-suited to the project's scale-up model to help ensure quality of delivery and promise of sustainability. In addition, this scale-up project will follow up with partner organizations to document and evaluate the customization of its resources on the frequency and impact of the partners' outreach. Finally, cyberlearning tools will expand the scope and reach of this project to help scale up and sustain the project's impact nationally.

Broader Impacts: The Role Models Matter project will have broad long-term impact through working with national partner groups to help role models engage, expand, and inspire girls in STEM careers. This coalition of partnerships will bring together girl-serving organizations with role models to promote and sustain widespread quality role model outreach. In addition, the best practices and lessons learned in scaling up and program sustainability will be disseminated broadly to a national audience of STEM professionals, corporations, researchers, practitioners and policymakers through publications and conference presentations. Such visibility will also serve to leverage community and national support.

ProgramElement.Text: RES ON GENDER IN SCI & ENGINE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through Role Models Matter (RMM), the overall project's objectives were to share Techbridge Girls' knowledge gained through 15 years of role model training with other STEM-focused girl-serving groups who could benefit from our lessons learned. Techbridge was well-positioned to leverage our expertise and resources, and collaborate with three strong national partners to demonstrate the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project. 

We knew one approach would not work for all, so the project enhanced and customized resources for partners, and a feedback loop was essential to the RMM project. Over the course of the past five years, we worked closely with our three organizational partners, the National Girls Collaborative Project (NGCP), Girl Scout councils, and the Society of Women Engineers (SWE), to listen closely and adapt what works at Techbridge Girls to respond to the needs of each of these unique organizations.

The data collected during the RMM project (over 1,600 survey responses, and 25+ interviews) indicates the training fulfilled a need and appears to improve the quality of STEM outreach. The data indicates that role model identity development is needed to become an active, engaged role model for youth in STEM, and that the RMM products developed in this project (customized guides, in-person trainings, webinars, and a website with 17 modules, many of which feature video of role model interactions with girls) can support that identity development for professionals, students, and educators. These initial findings impact identity literature as related to STEM identity development, STEM role model identity, and STEM pedagogy, as well as the informal learning body of research.

The project had a broader impact than originally anticipated, training at least 3,460 participants. Role Models Matter reached 974 participants at SWE training events and 836 participants via the National Girls Collaborative project. In addition, via partnerships with 10 Girl Scout councils, 1650+ received RMM training during the 5 year grant cycle. Each of the partners brought complementary core competencies, resources and a strong commitment to supporting this project across their memberships.  Additional unanticipated partners, including Million Women Mentors and US2020, expanded the reach further.  

In surveys conducted after in-person RMM training and an event/experience doing outreach with youth, our evaluator found significant positive impact on STEM role models that they attributed to RMM training. Four out of five participants said the training made them more confident in outreach (80%). Nearly all trainees (94%) said they were confident they conveyed their personal enthusiasm for science and/or engineering to youth. 82% said they described their work at their students’ level of understanding, and 76% said they made their work relevant to youths’ lives. The majority engaged youth in hands-on activities (84%), interacted with youth during their activity (82%) and led discussion about the activity (68%).  

When asked if the RMM training improved their work with youth, 84% agreed that the training influenced their work at least a bit, while many of those who did not report a change stated they had already had a lot of experience with youth. One participant stated “I was a better role model after the training because I know what the important things are to convey to the students!”

The secondary impact of the RMM project is difficult to capture but the project had a ripple-effect. There was an undocumented "second-level" of trainees; they were trained by Techbridge-trained RMM participants associated with the three partner organizations. The reach of the RMM training was, and continues, to grow, as the resources and relationships developed in this project continue past the grant's conclusion.

Lasting products from the RMM grant include a training website (www.techbridgegirls.org/rolemodelsmatter) with videos (also accessible via YouTube) and printed collateral to support educators and parents seeking to connect with STEM professionals, as well as potential STEM role models seeking support to improve their outreach techniques during classroom visits, STEM events, and field trips to STEM workplaces.

Techbridge Girls is committed to recruiting, training and supporting STEM role models as an essential component of our proven approach to "inspire a girl to change the world." The Role Models Matter project allowed us to further refine, share and scale our tested, proven approach across the country with three national partners who have broad reach across girl-serving organizations, STEM volunteers, universities, and corporations. 


 

 


Last Modified: 03/08/2017
Modified by: Jennifer Wei
